name: Jia-Ru (Edith) Chung
pitch: WHO & WHY: Right now, I have two AI product prototypes, and one area I want to understand deeply is how to make them scalable, distinct from ChatGPT, and capable of gaining larger market share. Since my current apps are powered by ChatGPT API keys, I want to explore whether leveraging AI evaluation through expert and generalist reviews can help, or whether building my own models is necessary. From a product and growth perspective, I’m focused on driving engagement at scale, measured through downloads, monthly clicks, repeat usage, and revenue. I want to better understand how research and experimentation can directly inform onboarding, retention loops, and monetization strategies, so insights translate into sustainable growth. My goal is to build products that move beyond early adopters by reducing friction, clarifying value quickly, and aligning AI behavior with real user intent—so engagement metrics improve alongside business outcomes.  I see strong value in collaborating with CTRL and SHIFT LAB to access resources, connect with AI communities, and have meaningful discussions around strategy and next steps for these prototypes. In parallel, I’m developing two additional apps, including an AI-powered styling recommendation product and a technical support matchmaking platform modeled after an on-demand marketplace. I’d love to connect with members across CTRL and SHIFT LAB to learn from their experience, pressure-test early product decisions, and access resources that support AI products at scale.  In parallel, I’m developing two additional apps, including an AI-powered styling recommendation product and a technical support matchmaking platform modeled after an on-demand marketplace. I’d love to connect with members across CTRL and SHIFT LAB to learn from their experience, pressure-test early product decisions, and access resources that support AI products at scale.
summary: Building multiple AI-powered consumer applications including styling recommendations and technical support matchmaking, currently using ChatGPT APIs and exploring scalability strategies.

name: Sandy Zhang
pitch: WHO & WHY: I want to explore how different AI tools affect decision making in real workflows, especially how model outputs, uncertainty, and explanations are shown to users. I am interested in how people interpret AI suggestions, when over reliance starts, and how interfaces can be designed to encourage thoughtful judgment instead of passive acceptance. In my first week, I would want to work directly with the tools used to build and evaluate AI systems, such as model APIs, prompt pipelines, and evaluation frameworks, to better understand how these systems are actually used in practice. More broadly, I believe AI should be part of everyday life as a foundational tool rather than something people compete with. What truly sets humans apart is creativity and individuality, and by handing off routine or repetitive tasks to AI, people have more time and mental space to think creatively and make higher level decisions. Instead of focusing on creating the next big AI breakthrough, I am more interested in making existing AI tools easy to access across different sectors, almost like shopping but for different AI tools, so individuals and organizations can focus less on short term execution and more on long term goals, strategy, and impact. Essentially creating a centralized hub for all AI usage and giving individuals the possibility to choose. With a centralized hub it's a lot easier to analyze user actions and how people use AI.   I would reach out to people who focus on making AI tools usable and accessible across different sectors. This includes product managers, platform engineers, and designers working on AI marketplaces, developer platforms, and model tooling, as well as researchers studying human-AI interaction and ethical use. I’d want to learn from people at large AI companies and from practitioners in fields like healthcare, education, and creative industries who are still learning to adopt these tools into their workflow. I would get involved by talking with them about their needs, then contribute by prototyping interfaces, evaluating tool usage, or helping design systems that make choosing and using AI tools feel more intuitive and transparent. I'll mostly find these people through the Princeton alumni network.
summary: Building a centralized hub/marketplace for AI tools while researching how different AI interfaces affect human decision-making and preventing over-reliance on AI systems.

name: Anusha Sarraf
pitch: WHO & WHY: I would love to know more about what you're building and I would love to work with Bijan Marashi.
summary: No clear product or business description provided in the application.

name: Ke Xiao
pitch: WHO & WHY: I’m drawn to CTRL SHIFT Lab because it combines everything I care about, building useful AI, thinking critically about where the field is going, and connecting with people who want to make technology serve human needs. I love experimenting with new models and tools, but I’m equally interested in the “why” behind them and the impact they create.  One area I’d like to dig into is how small, domain‑specific models or agents can make AI more personal and privacy‑safe. I’d like to explore ways to build lightweight local AI tools that let users control their own data while still benefiting from intelligent systems.  In my first week, I’d probably build a prototype for the link‑feed idea, something simple that gathers the most interesting new AI research, social posts, and open‑source projects and organizes them by theme and momentum. I’d use it as a way for the team to visualize where attention is moving each week.  To grow the community, I’d reach out to open‑source contributors working on agent frameworks, prompt evaluation tools, and model alignment research. I’d also connect with researchers and indie hackers who share experiments publicly and are excited to collaborate. My goal would be to help create a space where sharing early, rough ideas feels welcome and productive.
summary: Building lightweight local AI tools and a link-feed system to organize AI research, social posts, and open-source projects by theme and momentum.

name: Samuel Elias
pitch: WHO & WHY: I am someone who genuinely cares about cybersecurity and sees it as both a craft and a way to help people feel safer in a digital world. I spend a lot of time breaking down real attacks, analyzing network traffic, learning tools, and teaching myself how things work underneath. What excites me about CTRL SHIFT Lab is that you focus on building for real impact and for the people who use the technology, not just the next quick win. That matches how I think about security. The area I want to dig into is human centered cybersecurity. I want to explore how AI can support analysts by helping them think more clearly, spot patterns faster, and avoid burnout. A lot of security tooling overwhelms the human. I want to build things that guide people, explain what they are seeing, and make the work feel more approachable and meaningful. When people understand what is happening, they become more confident and capable. That is the type of future I want to contribute to.
summary: Building AI-powered cybersecurity tools that support human analysts by helping them understand threats, spot patterns, and avoid burnout through more intuitive interfaces.

name: Ricardo Antonio Sapien
pitch: WHO & WHY: I'm a senior full stack developer with over a decade of experience. I've built and scaled AI driven applications, which directly aligns with developing core technology.
summary: The application lacks specific details about what product or technology is being built, only mentioning the founder's background in AI-driven applications.

name: Srinayani Mankali
pitch: WHO & WHY: I’m most excited to dig deep into how agentic AI systems can be designed to be genuinely human-centered by default, not patched with safety or usability considerations later. That means researching how routing, guardrails, evaluation, and feedback loops shape real human outcomes—trust, clarity, and agency—rather than just model performance. In my recent work, I’ve seen how quickly capability can outpace thoughtful design, and I’m interested in identifying the real leverage points where AI can meaningfully support people in decision-making, creativity, and coordination. CTRL SHIFT Lab’s long-horizon, foundation-backed approach feels like the right environment to do this kind of reflective but hands-on research.In my first week, I’d focus on shipping something tangible. I’d start by extending or prototyping tooling around the CTRL SHIFT link feed—adding lightweight AI layers that help surface why something matters, not just what is trending. That could include clustering links by underlying themes or opportunities, generating concise, high-signal summaries for builders and researchers, and adding simple evaluation hooks to distinguish lasting insights from hype. I’m comfortable moving quickly from idea to working prototype, especially in Python-based agent or LLM tooling, and iterating in public with fast feedback.I’d actively reach out to builders, researchers, and early founders who are already thinking in public—especially those working on agentic systems, safety, and human-AI interaction. Rather than cold outreach, I’d engage thoughtfully with their work, start conversations around shared problems, and invite a small set into focused collaborations or discussions tied to what we’re building at the lab. Alongside that, I’d document what we’re learning openly so CTRL SHIFT Lab becomes known as a place for clarity, rigor, and momentum. To me, community building isn’t about growth metrics—it’s about earning trust by consistently doing meaningful work in the open.
summary: Building human-centered agentic AI systems with focus on routing, guardrails, and evaluation that prioritize trust and user agency over just model performance.

name: Abhay Singh Chauhan
pitch: WHO & WHY: I love to research in the vast tech and AI world, I believe that my skills will be put there best use for this.  I've worked for National Geographic in research Analysis and even making my own mind-map. While for AI aspect, I have experience in building projects that use AI on top to improve efficiency and make process easier.  I live far but will always be available to communicate and update, I'm very sincere with my work since my name is also attached with it plus I'll be meeting deadlines. Being a team player is also important and I'll cooperate in every situation by taking and providing help.
summary: A researcher with experience in AI projects focused on improving efficiency and making processes easier.

name: Cole Estrin
pitch: WHO & WHY: I'm a junior studying CS at Texas State University. I've built and maintain several live products that have over 75,000 total MAU: a temp email service (54k MAU, also a mobile version which has 18k downloads with paying subscribers via Stripe), a gaming analytics platform (20k MAU, $1200+ ad rev/month), and a Costco Price Tracker (4k MAU). I built all of this solo, so I'm very used to going from idea to shipped product quickly. I also have previous experience interning at a startup (AppRabbit).  First Week Software: I'd work on whatever you needed help with, but for the CTRL SHIFT link feed for instance I'd look at the codebase to understand the stack and patterns and look for quick wins as I get oriented and setup - things like bug fixes or UX improvements or small features.  Who I'd reach out to: I'd start by asking the team who in the network they think I should connect with. Beyond that, I'd look for researchers and founders working on AI applications that prioritize usability over novelty, like people building tools for specific communities rather than general-purpose models. Twitter and the YC community (e.g. watching Hacker News) would be good starting points for finding those people.
summary: A CS student who has built and maintains multiple live products with 75k+ total MAU including temp email service, gaming analytics platform, and price tracker.

name: Daniel Nguyen
pitch: WHO & WHY: I’m a software engineering student who builds fast and learns by shipping. I’ve worked across AI systems, backend infrastructure, and developer tooling, from deploying production ML services at my IBM fellowship building route optimization and notification platforms end to end.  I’m most interested in researching how AI products move from demos to tools people actually rely on, especially where UX, infrastructure, and model behavior intersect. In my first week, I’d dig into the CTRL SHIFT link feed, prototype tooling to surface meaningful AI trends, and explore lightweight AI workflows that help people make better decisions rather than just automate tasks.  I’d get involved by reaching out to builders and researchers already shipping practical AI, documenting experiments publicly, and contributing code, writing, and synthesis to grow the CTRL SHIFT community. This residency excites me because it values curiosity, speed, and real ownership, which is exactly how I like to work.
summary: A software engineering student researching how AI products transition from demos to reliable tools, focusing on the intersection of UX, infrastructure, and model behavior.

name: Nithin Reddy Yanna
pitch: WHO & WHY: about LLMs that discover new internal “reasoning circuits” and then lock them into a stable runtime (like a mini-compiler for thoughts).  I’d pull in (1) open-source builders (LangChain/LiteLLM/LiveKit communities; I've already contributed PRs to LiveKit Agents), (2) applied AI founders building workflow tools, and (3) researchers in interpretability/evals. I’d invite them via short DMs + a public “Build With Us” thread, then run a weekly micro-sprint: one problem, one prototype, one demo, published notes + repo links so others can fork and extend.
summary: Building LLMs that can discover and stabilize internal reasoning circuits, like a compiler for AI thoughts.

name: Krushna Bopparthi
pitch: WHO & WHY: I want to join CTRL SHIFT Lab because it’s one of the few communities genuinely thinking long-term about AI while still building in the present. The lab’s focus on people-centered AI, non-dilutive support, and experimentation aligns closely with how I approach technology—moving fast, but with intention and responsibility, not just short-term metrics.  What excites me most is the opportunity to build and learn alongside researchers, founders, and investors who are exploring meaningful, high-impact ideas. CTRL SHIFT Lab feels like a place where ambitious ideas can be tested, refined, and supported without being forced into premature commercialization, which is exactly the environment I’m looking for to create technology that actually improves lives.
summary: The application does not describe a specific product or technology being built, only explains motivation for joining the lab.

name: Kavin Sureshbabu
pitch: WHO & WHY: I am a product designer who deeply care about the user experience users get from products designed. With AI being on the rise I feel like there is a huge human to technology disconnect and people are starting to rely too much on ai because of the poor user quality that they have. Being in the Bay area and surrounded by tech startups I have also been very fond of company growth and what make a company succeed and what do not. I saw this role and I believe this would be a great opportunity for me to make an impact and learn a grow my design/research skills much more.
summary: The application lacks a clear product or business description, focusing instead on the applicant's background in product design and interest in improving AI user experiences.

name: Lisa Brown
pitch: WHO & WHY: My name is Lisa Brown, and my super power is curiosity. I teach myself tools on the weekends, and the Adobe product teams will tell you that I send them complex AI ideas and use cases for fun. I don't do it because I have to, or because I'm trying to get ahead somehow, I do it because I want to, because it brings me joy.   In my first 30 days, I would want to work on an idea I have about centralizing blockchain wallets around Dun and Bradstreet numbers and tying unique assets to the wallets to answer the question, how well is my brand performing in-market, as evidenced by asset engagement, and can this evidence in the distributed ledger contribute to a valid brand equity calculation?
summary: Building a blockchain-based system that centralizes wallets around D&B numbers to measure brand performance through asset engagement and calculate brand equity.

name: Mohamed Fadul
pitch: WHO & WHY: I’m Mohamed, a software engineer who loves using creativity to solve problems and turn ideas into real systems. I’ve worked on both large engineering teams at companies like Google, Clark Associates, and J.M. Smucker, and as a sole developer at Miller Bros Solar, where I built a full-scale solar monitoring system now used daily by their operations team. I’m constantly exploring new AI tools and building projects that combine data, automation, and intelligence to make technology more human-centered.  I want to dig deeper into generative video models and how they can be used to create more human-centered storytelling tools. I’ve been experimenting with video generation and motion consistency in my own projects, and I’m fascinated by how AI can extend creativity while keeping people in control of the narrative. In my first week, I would start building a lightweight tool that tracks and visualizes emerging trends in open-source AI projects, something that scrapes GitHub, ArXiv, and social feeds to surface what’s gaining traction in real time. It would help the team spot new ideas early and connect them to builders and researchers doing interesting work. I would also reach out to AI researchers, indie developers, and creative technologists experimenting with generative media and responsible AI, connecting through Twitter and Discord to grow a community that’s curious, open, and focused on building AI that amplifies human creativity rather than replacing it.
summary: Building a tool to track and visualize emerging trends in open-source AI projects by scraping GitHub, ArXiv, and social feeds, with a focus on generative video models for human-centered storytelling.

name: william zhao
pitch: WHO & WHY: I build things quickly, follow AI obsessively, and care a lot about whether the stuff we make actually helps real people.
summary: The application lacks specific details about what is being built, only mentioning a general focus on building things quickly and following AI developments.

name: Angel A. Barrera Gomez
pitch: WHO & WHY: I’m interested in researching how AI systems can be designed to remain useful, transparent, and trustworthy when data is messy, constraints are real, and humans stay in the loop. This interest is inspired by research I conducted on plant organ classification using 3D LiDAR point clouds. It was fascinating to see how an ML model learned almost like a toddler does, the more structured guidance it received, such as geometric features, the better it performed. I’m particularly curious about this “human training a machine” dynamic, both to ensure high-quality outputs and to maintain human control over the results, reducing risks like hallucinations or security breaches.  In my first week, I’d ship a small research-to-product tool; something that turns fast-moving AI developments into clear, actionable insights for builders and researchers. I’m particularly interested in implementing AI agents that can collaborate on tedious, repetitive tasks to improve the timing of research workflows. For example, during my previous research, I had to create a “ground truth” dataset by manually annotating plant organs in 3D space and assigning labels to each class so a convolutional neural network could learn and distinguish geometric forms. This process took about one hour per .pcd file, and the constraints were high since we needed at least 50 labeled point clouds. It ended up taking longer than anticipated, especially when dealing with edge cases. Developing an agentic AI system to assist with this process could significantly reduce annotation time and free researchers to focus more on experimentation and analysis.  I'm actively reach out to applied researchers and builders whose work aligns with human-centered AI. I have great relationship with the folks at Oak National Research Laboratory, Duke Energy, and Sandia Laboratory. Reaching out to them and document what I’m learning would be part of my goals, and use that visibility to strengthen the CTRL SHIFT Lab community.
summary: Building AI agents to collaborate on tedious research tasks like dataset annotation, starting with a tool that turns AI developments into actionable insights for builders and researchers.

Over the past few years, > I’ve built and shipped end-to-end AI products from RAG systems on financial > and academic data to real-time chat platforms, agentic workflows, and > ML-driven analytics used in production. I enjoy breaking down ambiguous problems, experimenting > with model behavior, evaluating tradeoffs in retrieval, latency, and > accuracy, and then translating those findings into decisions that shape > product direction. Whether it was optimizing RAG pipelines, fine-tuning > LLMs with LoRA, or designing systems that scale reliably under real user > load, I’ve always approached AI as something that must be studied, > measured, and refined not treated as a black box. > > I’m especially drawn to the research-to-product loop this role offers. I > want to ask hard questions about model behavior, user interaction, and > system design, run experiments to validate assumptions, and help turn those > insights into features people actually trust and use. name: Janakiram Sharma
pitch: WHO & WHY: I’m a full-stack engineer who sits right at the intersection of AI systems, product thinking, and real-world impact. Over the past few years, I’ve built and shipped end-to-end AI products  from RAG systems on financial and academic data to real-time chat platforms, agentic workflows, and ML-driven analytics used in production. What motivates me most is not just making models work, but understanding why they work, where they fail, and how to turn those insights into better products.  This residency excites me because it’s deeply aligned with how I already think and work. I enjoy breaking down ambiguous problems, experimenting with model behavior, evaluating tradeoffs in retrieval, latency, and accuracy, and then translating those findings into decisions that shape product direction. Whether it was optimizing RAG pipelines, fine-tuning LLMs with LoRA, or designing systems that scale reliably under real user load, I’ve always approached AI as something that must be studied, measured, and refined  not treated as a black box.  I’m especially drawn to the research-to-product loop this role offers. I want to ask hard questions about model behavior, user interaction, and system design, run experiments to validate assumptions, and help turn those insights into features people actually trust and use. This residency feels like the right environment to grow as an AI product researcher while contributing meaningfully from day one, given my background in building, evaluating, and shipping AI systems at scale.
summary: A full-stack engineer building end-to-end AI products including RAG systems, real-time chat platforms, and ML-driven analytics with a focus on understanding model behavior and translating insights into better products.

name: CTRL SHIFT
pitch: > WHO & WHY: > I’m Manvi Rankawat, a recent MSCS graduate who learns by building. > > I’ve shipped production features, owned live systems, and built AI agents > that adapt to uncertainty, including a fire-evacuation planner that > rethinks its path as hazards spread. I don’t wait for perfect specs. I > start, break things, fix them, and share what works. > > CTRL SHIFT Lab excites me because it treats AI as something to shape, not > chase. I want to help turn curiosity into tools, research into clarity, and > a community into momentum. > > >
